comments.body:
We should `break` here?

Or all/one of pods activate, we call `p.cond.Broadcast()`?

> We should `break` here?

Nope, we should activate every pod, and call `p.cond.Broadcast()` once at least one pod gets activated successfully.

why not just remove it in this PR?
I'd leave it for a 2nd PR just so that this PR is easier to port
sg if we are planning to cherrypick.
what about just accepting the namespaces lister?
not sure it matters much... may be we will need another lister in the future..
I think we'd better add pod key/value in the error logs as well.
We can't get the pod information because podInfo is nil when something goes wrong.
lgtm, but I cannot see what's the real impact, the pods in the activeQ will still be popped up with the original order.

If the Pod in activeQ have the same priority, they will be FIFO according to the enqueue time.
If the enqueue time is refreshed, the order in the activeQ should be updated. 
So I donâ€™t think should refresh the enqueue time
Another justification to also have the processed information in the queues.
yeah, the initial thought was to have a single PodInfo type, I think we can get that benefit back by embedding PodInfo in QueuedPodInfo.
This logic looks strange - for PodAffinity, isn't it needed to match ALL terms? Why it adds the pod upon first match?
Not really. The other affinity terms might be satisfied by other pods. But ultimately, this is just a heuristic.

> The other affinity terms might be satisfied by other pods.

Good point, however it's not the current semantics yet. See the history discussion #68701. And it reminds me of a closed implementation (#68725) I tried - I gave up due to non-trivial code changes by that time. Maybe now it's a good time to re-consider "Support inter-Pod affinity to multiple Pods" as codebase is a lot neater :)
shouldn't the other two functions be removed now? ```PriorityQueue.NominatedPodsForNode``` and ```nominatedPodMap.podsForNode```
Done.
when do we determine if the TODO is true or not? Seems like we'll probably never return if it doesn't cause a bug. Is there a way to add a unit test?

Basically it's impossible to use UT to cover potential error is user side, esp. some users are out of k/k.

Still it's quite related with how caller use it - append pod to the slice is ok, but good with modifying the element using `slice[i]=newPod`.
ignore this TODO when reviewing - it's covered in the next PR.
Add unit test for `Update` that exercises what we discussed.
Please pay attention to this change. I think the logic was duplicated therefore I refactored the interface method to call the helper method `movePodsToActiveOrBackoffQueue` directly.

it is different, in this implementation you are not adding back to the unschedulableQ the pods that we failed to move.

perhaps modify movePodsToActiveOrBackoffQueue to return addErrorPods so that MoveAllToActiveOrBackoffQueue can add them back to the unschedulable queue

In `movePodsToActiveOrBackoffQueue`, the pods that fail to be moved are not deleted from `UnschedulableQ` at the first place - `unschedulableQ.delete(pod)` is only called in the `else` branch where the move is complete.

comments.body: how can i configure the max duration if i do not want to default it ?

This is a pattern which used widely in the kubernetes codebase.

```go
NewPrioirtyQueue(
  stopCh,
  fwk.
  internalqueue.WithPodMaxBackoffDuration(500*time.Second),
  internalqueue.WithClock(xx),
)
```
I mean how can i  set the max duration value, any flag for that ? or add it somewhere ?
Every time i want to change the value, i need to modify the code ?

ok, it turns out that we can define constants in kubernetes/pkg/scheduler/apis/config/types.go, and as long as we don't add those constants to staging/src/k8s.io/kube-scheduler/config/v1alpha1/types.go, then they are not part of the API. What do you think about doing that?

> ok, it turns out that we can define constants in kubernetes/pkg/scheduler/apis/config/types.go, and as long as we don't add those constants to staging/src/k8s.io/kube-scheduler/config/v1alpha1/types.go, then they are not part of the API. What do you think about doing that?

Do we have precedence on such a thing? I'm ok with it if there was one.

It is up to us, no precedence is required here. k8s don't guarantee any level of compatibility with any source we produce that is not published for consumption as a go library (we only guarantee that for things we publish under the ```staging``` directory), we have strong guarantees only for REST APIs, config file yaml/json and binary flags. That being said, I will leave it up to you to decide.

After some digging, I prefer to keep it **as it is**. Even if we define the constants in `pkg/scheduler/apis/config/types.go`, we still need to use hard code value here https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/81263/files#diff-9d72b6493a5482d8a2829af1390c5733R106-R115 since the package shouldn't depend on other k8s.io/kubernetes code.

https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/1e761470ad8fa06b50bce99e483f556023b99524/pkg/scheduler/apis/config/v1alpha1/defaults.go#L23-L31
sg, please squash.

> sg, please squash.

done, please take a look
@draveness Regrading  https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/81263/files#r325523994. Are you saying `pkg/scheduler/apis/config/v1alpha1` should not import `pkg/scheduler/apis/config`?

> @draveness Regrading https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/81263/files#r325523994. Are you saying `pkg/scheduler/apis/config/v1alpha1` should not import `pkg/scheduler/apis/config`?

Yes, it documents in the `pkg/scheduler/apis/config/v1alpha1/defaults.go` where I listed above
A neat way is `nodeName = npm.nominatedPodToNode[oldPod.UID]`. If oldPod.UID doesn't exist, a nil string is returned.

This change makes the logic more robust, but `nodeName` should not be initialized with empty string. It should be initialized by `NominatedNodeName(newPod)`. Otherwise, all usual updates that do not come inside this `if` statement, would remove nominated pods.

Initilizing `nodeName` as empty string should be good b/c in nominatedPodMap.add(), it checks if incoming nodeName is empty; if it is, it calls NominatedNodeName(p):

https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/314264aeafb94d4948a3f117bcc4382eba10dede/pkg/scheduler/internal/queue/scheduling_queue.go#L735-L746
You are right.

A nit: as you wrap the detailed msg here as an `err`, and re-wrap the err msg in caller side, I suppose we'll get a sort of duplicate err msg? Like:

```
Error add unschedulable pod <pod> to queue: error adding pod <pod> to the backoff queue: <err>.
```

Maybe it's better wrapping the detailed msg only in one side - (1) either wrap here and in caller side simply log `klog.Errorf(err)`, or (2) simply return err here and in caller side log `klog.Errorf("Error add unschedulable pod %v to queue: %v", pod, err)`.

(1) is more preferable IMO.
Yeah, that's a good one. Updated the code in caller site with `klog.Errorf(err)`. Please take a look at the latest commit.
As you already have `NewPodBackoffMapWithDefaultTime()`, suggest to use that directly.

`NewPodBackoffMapWithDefaultTime()` is used in factory.go with `1*time.Second` and `60*time.Second` and here in scheduling_queue we have `1*time.Second` and `10*time.Second`. Shall we keep the original time duration or change to 1 and 10 secs in both place?
Oh, I misread.. I thought all default backoff threshold is 10 seconds. Then don't bother. Keep them as is.

comments.body: Done. Thank you.
nits: one last request is could you please add a comment to explain this `SchedulingCycle` interface a bit? It would be helpful to upcoming contributors.
Also, a comment for `AddUnschedulableIfNotPresent` to explain `podSchedulingCycle int64`.
Comments are added. PTAL.

Looking at the code on line 414, it seems the condition should be (without =) :

podSchedulingCycle > p.moveRequestCycle

`Greater than or equal` is correct. In fact, it is very important to have =. Equal means that a move request is received in the same scheduling cycle as the pod was being scheduled. So, it is likely that the scheduler has not seen the changes that led to the move request yet and didn't use those changes when making a scheduling decision. As a result, the pod must be retried if it is unschedulable.
Done.

At line 536, we clear backoff of a pod that is updated and is in the unschedulableQ. We then move it directly to the activeQ. Shouldn't we do the same for a pod in the BackoffQ to be consistent? I mean we should clear its backoff and move it to the activeQ if it is updated.
Yep, I agree - done.
We must check the BackoffQ and delete the pod from there if it exists.
